Things back the way they

Jun 24, 2017

Good evening, readers. Last time, so much has happened, in sense of project, surely.

Let me introduce a little bit my project to make clear the previous post. As I was saying before, I am working on advanced syscall information tool. What is that? Actually, the name speaks for itself. Literally, this tool is purposed to work with stored database about syscalls. Where am I going to get this database? It has already existed.

The strace contains special files, syscallent.h’s, for different architectures and stores basic info about system calls, for instance (strace/linux/x86_64/syscallent.h:1):

where,
3 - number of arguments;
TD - flags for system calls to be grouped (here - file descriptor-related system call);
SEN(read) - converts read to SEN_read(int) and sys_read(ponter to function);
“read” - just the system call name.

Now, everything which is necessary to implement initial functionality - just use these files. Therefore, the asinfo tool has the following architecture:

As for architectures, the asinfo has get-arch, list-arch, set-arch %name_of_arch options, arch_dispatcher is purposed to process these options. As a return value, subroutine provides array of arch_descriptor’s:

Concerning managing with system calls, the asinfo has get-num, get-nargs, get-proto, get-kernel, list-syscall options. Based on request, the syscall_dispatcher will return the corresponding structures, for example, typing:

syscall_dispatcher will return the following structure:

where struct sc_base_info is:

After that, the result will be printed:

Now, to consider the filter_dispatcher, let’s enter the next one command:

Firstly, arch_dispatcher will return the current architecture, after that syscall_dispatcher will provide the list of system calls (struct sc_base_info) for this architecture, finally filter_dispatcher working with syscallent’s database will drop all system calls, which are not signal-related.

The last one detail, how to convert set-arch option to request for arch_dispatcher? For this purpose, there is special function form_req:

Oh, State Examination is acting up… That brings me to the end of my post. Next time, I am about to describe the push-back interface with list of arch_descriptor and something more. And yes, the previous post was an example of list-arch command.

Watch for updates!
